metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S.K. Habibullah

facts.text: S.K. Mohideen (assessee) was a partner in two registered firms: Messrs. Dinshaw and Co. and Messrs. Palanippa Chettiar and Co.

Assessee submitted returns for assessment year 1946-47 incorporating estimated share of losses: Rs. 20,000/- in Dinshaw and Rs. 10,000/- in Palanippa; for 1947-48: Rs. nil in Dinshaw and Rs. 12,436/- in Palanippa.

Income-tax Officer, V Circle, Madras completed assessments for 1946-47 and 1947-48 on February 20, 1950, adopting assessee's estimates but noting losses subject to revision on ascertainment of correct particulars.
Assessment of Messrs. Dinshaw & Co. for 1946-47 and 1947-48 completed on October 31, 1950 by ITO II Circle, Madras; assessee's share of losses: Rs. 15,839/- and Rs. 1,046/- respectively.
Assessment of Messrs. Palanippa Chettiar & Co. for 1947-48 completed on June 30, 1951 by ITO Special Circle; assessee's share of loss: Rs. 2,009/-.
On receipt of firms' assessment intimations, ITO V Circle issued notices on May 4, 1953 to show cause why assessee's assessments for 1946-47 and 1947-48 should not be rectified under s. 35.
Assessee wrote to ITO on March 24, 1954: 'This is to inform you that I have no objection in completing the assessments of the previous years in accordance with law.'
ITO revised assessee's assessments on March 27, 1954 taking into account shares of losses as computed in firms' assessments.
S.K. Habibullah (respondent, assessee's son) applied to Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras for revision of ITO's orders; CIT held s. 35 properly invoked and rejected applications.
Madras High Court in W.P. No. 952 of 1955 (judgment dated April 10, 1957) ordered writs of certiorari quashing ITO's orders.
Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras appealed to Supreme Court with certificate of fitness from High Court.
Assessments of both firms completed before April 1, 1952; assessee's assessments were final under s. 23(3).

legal_issues.text: Whether Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction under s. 35(5) of the Income-tax Act to rectify the assessee's assessment consequent upon assessment of the firm completed before April 1, 1952.
Whether assessee's letter assenting to rectification validated the ITO's action if unauthorized by law.
Whether mistake in partner's assessment discovered from firm's assessment is 'mistake apparent from the record' under s. 35(1).

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee assented to rectification by letter dated March 24, 1954, so respondent cannot challenge ITO's authority.
Mistake apparent from record under s. 35(1); s. 35(5) enacted ex abundanti cautela.
S. 35(5) applies to rectify partner's assessment based on firm's assessment even if firm assessed before April 1, 1952.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 35(5) as inserted by Indian Income-tax Amendment Act, 1953

respondent_arguments.text: No jurisdiction under s. 35 to rectify as mistake not apparent from record of partner's assessment but discovered from firm's assessment.
S. 35(5) not applicable as firms' assessments completed before its commencement on April 1, 1952; provision not retrospective.

court_reasoning.text: Assessee's assent does not validate unauthorized action; if law did not authorize rectification, assent cannot validate it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assent to rectification according to law does not cure lack of authority.

court_reasoning.text: Mistake discovered from firm's assessment is not 'mistake apparent from the record' of partner's assessment under s. 35(1); individual and firm are distinct entities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Record of firm's assessment not part of partner's assessment record.

court_reasoning.text: S. 35(5) creates fiction deeming inclusion/correction of partner's share as mistake apparent from record, with 4-year period from firm's final order; enacted to fill lacuna as not possible under s. 35(1).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not ex abundanti cautela; provides new power.

court_reasoning.text: S. 35(5) has partial retrospective operation from April 1, 1952; affects vested rights, not procedural; cannot extend beyond plain words.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Final assessments cannot be reopened except per ss. 34/35; power under s. 35(5) only for firms assessed on/after April 1, 1952.

court_reasoning.text: Contrast with s. 35(6) which expressly applies to pre-1953 assessments; absence in s. 35(5) confirms no larger retrospectivity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature knew how to provide for pre-commencement cases but did not for s. 35(5).

holdings.text: No jurisdiction under s. 35(5) to rectify partner's assessment consequent upon firm's assessment completed before April 1, 1952.
Assessee's assent does not validate rectification unauthorized by law.
Mistake from firm's assessment not apparent from partner's record under s. 35(1).

precedents_cited.case_name: Kanmarlapudi Lakshminarayana Chetty v. First Additional Income-tax Officer, Nellore
precedents_cited.relevance: Record of firm's assessment not part of partner's; mistake not apparent from partner's record.
Final assessments final except per ss. 34/35; provisions exhaustive.
S. 35(5) not declaratory; effective from April 1, 1952; affects vested rights.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs rectification of mistakes apparent from record; s. 35(5) deems partner's share adjustment as such mistake from firm's order.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax (Amendment) Act, 1953 (25 of 1953)
statutes_cited.relevance: Inserted s. 35(5) effective April 1, 1952 with partial retrospectivity.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court issued writs of certiorari under this.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals filed by Commissioner of Income-tax, holding no jurisdiction under s. 35(5) to rectify assessee's assessments based on firms' assessments completed before April 1, 1952, affirming High Court's quashing of ITO's rectification orders.
outcome.relief_granted: Writs of certiorari upheld; rectification orders quashed.

key_quotes.text: "But if the law did not authorise the Income-tax Officer to rectify the assessment, assent could not validate what was unauthorised."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects plea based on assessee's assent.

key_quotes.text: "a mistake discovered because of something contained in the assessment of the firm is not a mistake apparent from the record of assessment of the individual partner."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of 'mistake apparent from record' under s. 35(1).

key_quotes.text: "The power to rectify assessment of a partner consequent upon the assessment of the firm of which he is a partner by including or correcting his share of profit or loss can therefore be exercised only in case of assessment of the firm made on or after April 1, 1952."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on retrospectivity of s. 35(5).
